policies.name: Cryptographic Protection Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy defining approved cryptographic types and algorithms for protecting CUI confidentiality
policies.rationale: NIST 03.13.11 requires implementing 'organization-defined types of cryptography' which necessitates formal policy defining which cryptographic standards are approved (FIPS-validated recommended)

policies.name: Data Protection Policy
policies.description: High-level policy governing protection of CUI confidentiality through encryption
policies.rationale: Control requires protecting CUI confidentiality; policy establishes organizational commitment to cryptographic protection across all systems

procedures.name: Cryptographic Implementation Standards
procedures.description: Technical standards specifying approved algorithms, key lengths, cryptographic modules, and implementation requirements
procedures.rationale: Control requires implementing specific types of cryptography; procedure provides technical guidance on FIPS 140-2/140-3 validated modules, approved algorithms (AES-256, RSA-2048+), and configuration requirements

procedures.name: Cryptographic Module Selection and Deployment Procedure
procedures.description: Process for selecting, validating, and deploying cryptographic modules across systems handling CUI
procedures.rationale: Ensures only approved, FIPS-validated cryptographic modules are deployed; supports proper implementation of cryptographic protection

executionEvidence.name: Cryptographic Module Inventory
executionEvidence.description: Inventory showing: all cryptographic modules deployed, FIPS validation certificate numbers, systems where deployed, validation expiration dates, compliance status
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates implementation of approved cryptography; quarterly review aligns with configuration management best practices and ensures FIPS validation remains current

executionEvidence.name: FIPS Validation Certificates
executionEvidence.description: Copies of FIPS 140-2 or FIPS 140-3 validation certificates for all cryptographic modules in use
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion recommends FIPS-validated cryptography for CUI protection; certificates prove compliance with federal cryptographic standards

executionEvidence.name: Encryption Status Reports
executionEvidence.description: Configuration reports showing: BitLocker status on endpoints, database encryption enabled, TLS configuration on web servers, file share encryption status, percentage of systems encrypted
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates cryptographic protection is actively deployed and functioning; monthly frequency allows prompt detection of encryption failures

executionEvidence.name: Cryptographic Compliance Scan Results
executionEvidence.description: Automated scan reports showing: systems scanned, weak algorithms detected (MD5, SHA-1, DES), deprecated protocols identified (SSLv3, TLS 1.0), remediation status
executionEvidence.rationale: Validates ongoing compliance with cryptographic standards; identifies systems using outdated/weak cryptography requiring remediation

operationalActivities: Deploy only FIPS 140-2 or FIPS 140-3 validated cryptographic modules
Enable BitLocker or equivalent full-disk encryption on all endpoints handling CUI
Configure TLS 1.2 or higher for all data in transit
Review cryptographic module inventory quarterly and remove deprecated modules
Scan systems monthly for weak or deprecated cryptographic algorithms
Maintain current FIPS validation certificates for all cryptographic modules
Replace cryptographic modules when FIPS validation expires
Monitor NIST guidance for deprecated algorithms and plan migration

policies.name: Acceptable Use Policy
policies.description: Policy governing acceptable use of collaborative computing devices including cameras, microphones, and conferencing applications
policies.rationale: NIST 03.13.12 requires prohibiting remote activation of collaborative devices; policy establishes organizational position on device usage and security requirements

policies.name: Remote Work and Telework Policy
policies.description: Policy addressing security requirements for remote workers using cameras, microphones, and collaboration tools
policies.rationale: Control discussion emphasizes notebook computers, smartphones, and tablets with cameras/microphones used in remote work scenarios

procedures.name: Collaborative Device Configuration Procedure
procedures.description: Step-by-step process for configuring cameras, microphones, and conferencing software to prevent unauthorized remote activation
procedures.rationale: Control requires prohibiting remote activation; procedure provides technical steps for disabling remote activation features in conferencing tools (Zoom, Teams, WebEx)

procedures.name: Video Conferencing Security Procedure
procedures.description: Hardening standards for video conferencing applications including required security settings and usage indicators
procedures.rationale: Control requires explicit indication of use to users; procedure ensures conferencing tools display active status (recording indicator, microphone active light)

procedures.name: Physical Security Control Distribution Procedure
procedures.description: Process for distributing and tracking physical webcam covers and microphone disable buttons to employees
procedures.rationale: NIST discussion mentions 'webcam covers and buttons to disable microphones' as solutions; procedure ensures physical controls are provided

executionEvidence.name: Collaborative Device Configuration Reports
executionEvidence.description: Endpoint management reports showing: devices inventoried with cameras/microphones, remote activation settings disabled, approved conferencing software installed, configuration compliance status by device
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates technical implementation of remote activation prevention; quarterly aligns with configuration management review cycles

executionEvidence.name: Conferencing Software Policy Compliance Reports
executionEvidence.description: Reports showing: conferencing applications deployed, security settings configured (require explicit consent, display active indicators), policy violations detected, remediation status
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requires explicit indication of use; monthly monitoring ensures conferencing tools maintain required security settings

executionEvidence.name: Remote Activation Exception Approvals
executionEvidence.description: Documentation of approved exceptions showing: requestor, business justification, specific devices/applications approved, approval authority, approval date, periodic review dates
executionEvidence.rationale: Control allows 'organization-defined exceptions where remote activation is to be allowed'; documentation proves deliberate, authorized exceptions with appropriate approval

executionEvidence.name: Collaborative Device Security Training Records
executionEvidence.description: Training certificates showing: employee name, training date, topics covered (webcam security, microphone privacy, recognizing active indicators), acknowledgment signatures
executionEvidence.rationale: Users must understand device security requirements and recognize active use indicators; annual training ensures awareness

executionEvidence.name: Physical Control Distribution Records
executionEvidence.description: Inventory showing: webcam covers distributed by employee, hardware disable switches provided, acknowledgment of receipt, device serial numbers
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion mentions physical controls; records prove organization provided physical webcam covers and disable mechanisms

physicalEvidence.name: Webcam Cover Procurement Documentation
physicalEvidence.description: Purchase orders and inventory records for physical webcam covers distributed to employees
physicalEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion explicitly mentions 'webcam covers' as solutions to prevent device usage; physical evidence proves organizational implementation

physicalEvidence.name: Sample Device Photos with Physical Controls
physicalEvidence.description: Photographs showing webcam covers installed on organizational devices and hardware microphone disable buttons
physicalEvidence.rationale: Visual evidence demonstrates physical controls are actually implemented as stated in procedures

operationalActivities: Configure all endpoint devices to disable remote activation of cameras and microphones by default
Install and configure video conferencing software with required security settings
Distribute physical webcam covers to all employees with devices containing cameras
Ensure conferencing applications display explicit indicators when camera/microphone is active
Document and approve any business-justified exceptions for remote activation
Review remote activation exceptions quarterly to ensure continued business need
Provide annual security training on collaborative device risks and protections
Monitor endpoint compliance with collaborative device configuration standards

policies.name: Mobile Code Policy
policies.description: Policy defining acceptable and unacceptable mobile code technologies, usage restrictions, and authorization requirements
policies.rationale: NIST 03.13.13.a requires 'define acceptable mobile code and mobile code technologies'; policy formally establishes what mobile code is permitted (JavaScript, HTML5) and prohibited (VBScript, unsigned ActiveX)

policies.name: Web Browser Security Policy
policies.description: Policy governing browser security settings, plugin restrictions, and mobile code controls
policies.rationale: Control discussion states 'usage restrictions and implementation guidelines apply to...workstations and devices'; policy provides organizational requirements for browser hardening

policies.name: Application Security Policy
policies.description: Policy requiring digital signatures for mobile code and defining code signing requirements
policies.rationale: NIST discussion states mobile code policies 'address...requiring mobile code to be digitally signed by a trusted source'

procedures.name: Mobile Code Authorization Procedure
procedures.description: Process for requesting, evaluating, and approving use of new mobile code technologies including risk assessment and approval workflow
procedures.rationale: Control 03.13.13.b requires 'authorize, monitor, and control the use of mobile code'; procedure defines how mobile code requests are evaluated and approved

procedures.name: Browser Security Configuration Procedure
procedures.description: Technical hardening standards for web browsers including disabling dangerous plugins, restricting script execution, and configuring Content Security Policy
procedures.rationale: Control requires monitoring and controlling mobile code; procedure provides technical implementation for restricting JavaScript, disabling ActiveX, and preventing malicious scripts

procedures.name: Application Control Implementation Procedure
procedures.description: Process for deploying application control policies (AppLocker, Windows Defender Application Control) to block unauthorized mobile code execution
procedures.rationale: Control requires controlling mobile code use; application control provides technical enforcement preventing execution of unapproved mobile code

executionEvidence.name: Browser Configuration Compliance Reports
executionEvidence.description: Configuration scans showing: browsers deployed, JavaScript restrictions configured, plugin/extension allowlist applied, unsafe protocols blocked, compliance percentage by device
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates technical controls for mobile code are consistently applied; monthly frequency allows timely detection of configuration drift

executionEvidence.name: Application Control Policy Reports
executionEvidence.description: Reports showing: application control rules deployed, blocked mobile code execution attempts, unsigned scripts prevented, violation details (user, timestamp, script), remediation actions
executionEvidence.rationale: Provides evidence that mobile code controls are actively blocking unauthorized code; weekly frequency appropriate for security monitoring

executionEvidence.name: Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) Reports
executionEvidence.description: Defender ASR reports showing: obfuscated script blocking events, JavaScript/VBScript threat detections, devices protected, block vs audit mode status
executionEvidence.rationale: ASR specifically targets obfuscated mobile code threats mentioned in NIST discussion; weekly monitoring ensures malicious mobile code is detected and blocked

executionEvidence.name: Mobile Code Authorization Requests and Approvals
executionEvidence.description: Records showing: technology requested, business justification, risk assessment performed, approval authority, approval date, periodic review schedule
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requires authorizing mobile code use; documentation proves formal approval process is followed for each mobile code technology

executionEvidence.name: Endpoint Security Logs - Script Blocking
executionEvidence.description: Aggregated logs showing: blocked script execution attempts, malicious mobile code detections, quarantined scripts, affected systems
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates continuous monitoring of mobile code; daily review critical for detecting mobile code attacks in progress

operationalActivities: Configure browsers with restricted JavaScript execution policies
Deploy application control policies to block unsigned mobile code
Enable Defender Attack Surface Reduction rules for obfuscated script blocking
Review and approve mobile code authorization requests with risk assessment
Monitor endpoint security logs daily for blocked mobile code execution attempts
Update browser security configurations as new mobile code threats emerge
Maintain allowlist of approved mobile code technologies and digital signatures
Disable or restrict high-risk mobile code technologies (ActiveX, VBScript)
Review quarterly all approved mobile code technologies for continued business need

policies.name: Network Security Policy
policies.description: Policy requiring authenticated communication sessions and protection against session-based attacks
policies.rationale: NIST 03.13.15 requires 'protect the authenticity of communications sessions'; policy establishes organizational requirement for session authentication mechanisms

policies.name: Encryption and Cryptographic Standards Policy
policies.description: Policy mandating use of authenticated encryption protocols (TLS, IPsec) for all communications sessions
policies.rationale: Control requires session authenticity; policy defines required protocols that provide both encryption and authentication (TLS 1.2+, IPsec with authentication)

procedures.name: Secure Communications Configuration Procedure
procedures.description: Technical implementation guide for configuring TLS, HTTPS, SSH, and other authenticated protocols across systems
procedures.rationale: Control requires protecting session authenticity; procedure provides specific configuration steps for implementing authenticated protocols with strong cipher suites

procedures.name: PKI Certificate Management Procedure
procedures.description: Process for acquiring, deploying, renewing, and revoking PKI certificates used for session authentication
procedures.rationale: Session authenticity typically relies on certificate-based authentication; procedure ensures certificates are properly managed to maintain trust

procedures.name: Network Security Monitoring Procedure
procedures.description: Process for detecting and responding to session hijacking, adversary-in-the-middle attacks, and session anomalies
procedures.rationale: NIST discussion states authenticity protection includes 'protecting against adversary-in-the-middle attacks, session hijacking'; monitoring procedure defines detection methods

executionEvidence.name: TLS Configuration Scan Reports
executionEvidence.description: Scan results showing: web servers/applications scanned, TLS versions enabled (require 1.2+), cipher suite strength, certificate validity, protocol vulnerabilities detected (POODLE, BEAST, etc.), SSL Labs grade
executionEvidence.rationale: TLS provides session authentication and protects against man-in-the-middle attacks; monthly scans ensure configurations remain secure and current with best practices

executionEvidence.name: Certificate Inventory and Validity Reports
executionEvidence.description: Reports showing: all PKI certificates deployed, issuing CA, expiration dates, certificate purposes (web server, code signing), validity status, upcoming expirations
executionEvidence.rationale: Valid, trusted certificates are essential for session authenticity; monthly reviews ensure certificates don't expire and break session authentication

executionEvidence.name: Network Traffic Analysis - Encrypted Session Usage
executionEvidence.description: Reports showing: total network sessions analyzed, percentage using authenticated encryption (TLS/IPsec), unencrypted session protocols detected, systems transmitting unencrypted CUI
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates authenticated protocols are actually in use for communications; identifies systems failing to implement session authenticity

executionEvidence.name: IDS/IPS Alerts - Session-Based Attacks
executionEvidence.description: Security event logs showing: detected adversary-in-the-middle attempts, session hijacking indicators, SSL stripping attacks, rogue certificate warnings, investigation status
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion emphasizes protecting against session hijacking and MITM attacks; daily monitoring critical for detecting attacks attempting to compromise session authenticity

executionEvidence.name: Web Application Security Scan Results
executionEvidence.description: Scan reports showing: applications tested, HTTPS enforcement verified, HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) enabled, secure cookie flags set, session fixation vulnerabilities
executionEvidence.rationale: Web applications are primary target for session attacks; quarterly security scans verify session protection mechanisms properly implemented

operationalActivities: Configure all web servers and applications to use TLS 1.2 or higher
Disable legacy SSL/TLS protocols vulnerable to session attacks (SSLv3, TLS 1.0, TLS 1.1)
Implement certificate-based authentication for session establishment
Deploy and maintain valid PKI certificates from trusted certificate authorities
Monitor network traffic for unencrypted communication sessions
Configure IDS/IPS to detect session hijacking and man-in-the-middle attacks
Enable HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) on all web applications
Review monthly TLS configuration scans and remediate weak configurations
Replace expiring certificates proactively (30-60 days before expiration)
Block or alert on untrusted certificate usage
Perform quarterly security scans of web applications for session vulnerabilities
